channel.title: Motorcycles
channel.description:
Answer any of the following:
1. What is your favorite motorcycle in terms of performance and design?
2. If you could have any motorcycle in the world, which would you pick?
3. What motorcycle do you currently have?
I personally like the Harley Davidson Sportster, but I do not know what motorcycle I'd get if I could have any.
Post pictures if you like!

item.title: Motorcycles
item.dc:creator: @mormonman mormonman
item.description:
@mormonman wrote:

[quote=“Ruby, post:46, topic:430531”][quote author=mormonman link=topic=533211.msg4115046#msg4115046 date=1348957980]
I’m currently riding a Ninja 250r, had it for about 2 months, and I’m already wanting something a little bigger. I love the maneuverability of it, its amazing compared to other bikes I have ridden(sv500, gxsr650, sv650). Are there other bikes I might enjoy with more power(I’m not really looking for a monster 1000) but still some wonderful handling?
[/quote]

You can’t really take the handling of a 250 to a bigger bike, it’s part of them. If you want something with good handling I’d say an Er-6n. Brilliant looking, fast, great gearbox, excellent handling.[/quote]

I’ve heard they don’t have that much more torque, especially for a 650.

Read full topic

mormonman:

I’m currently riding a Ninja 250r, had it for about 2 months, and I’m already wanting something a little bigger. I love the maneuverability of it, its amazing compared to other bikes I have ridden(sv500, gxsr650, sv650). Are there other bikes I might enjoy with more power(I’m not really looking for a monster 1000) but still some wonderful handling?

You can’t really take the handling of a 250 to a bigger bike, it’s part of them. If you want something with good handling I’d say an Er-6n. Brilliant looking, fast, great gearbox, excellent handling.

item.title: Motorcycles
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

[quote=“Ve_T, post:43, topic:430531”]I remember that stage. At least you have a sporty 125. I had to put up with a Honda Xr125L6 for a year (Done my car test first and bike after… didn’t have my priorities right at that time in my life :P) and that had a top speed of around 55-60mph lol.

I’ve never ridden an ER-6n but I’ve read and heard brilliant reviews about them and they seem to be good little supertwin bikes.

I’m only 19 but I know a few people who run dealerships so they let me out on there demonstrators for test rides. When I passed my test I had ended up with a 2007 SV650S which was an awesome machine for what it was. Although I out grew it in around 6 months and all the flaws started to show (Cheap suspension, crap chassis, horrible wheel size etc). Since then I’ve gone through a range of bikes, in ownership: Suzuki TS50X, Honda XR125, Suzuki SV650S, Suzuki DRZ400E, CCM 604E SM, '09 Triumph Street Triple and my current bike a 09 Daytona 675SE.

It’s taken me quite a few changes to realize what sort of bike fits me and my riding style. Though, I still want another supermoto in my life.[/quote]

You’ve went through quite a few bikes :P. I wouldn’t mind a 600 Bandit when I pass my bike test. I’d just more or less turn it into a streetfighter. Either that or an XJ-6, they’re also brilliant bikes.

Read full topic

item.title: Motorcycles
item.dc:creator: @Ve_T Ve_T
item.description:
@Ve_T wrote:

I remember that stage. At least you have a sporty 125. I had to put up with a Honda Xr125L6 for a year (Done my car test first and bike after… didn’t have my priorities right at that time in my life :P) and that had a top speed of around 55-60mph lol.

I’ve never ridden an ER-6n but I’ve read and heard brilliant reviews about them and they seem to be good little supertwin bikes.

I’m only 19 but I know a few people who run dealerships so they let me out on there demonstrators for test rides. When I passed my test I had ended up with a 2007 SV650S which was an awesome machine for what it was. Although I out grew it in around 6 months and all the flaws started to show (Cheap suspension, crap chassis, horrible wheel size etc). Since then I’ve gone through a range of bikes, in ownership: Suzuki TS50X, Honda XR125, Suzuki SV650S, Suzuki DRZ400E, CCM 604E SM, '09 Triumph Street Triple and my current bike a 09 Daytona 675SE.

It’s taken me quite a few changes to realize what sort of bike fits me and my riding style. Though, I still want another supermoto in my life.

Read full topic

item.title: Motorcycles
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

[quote=“Ve_T, post:41, topic:430531”]I test rode an R6. Personally I thought it was a bit too top end orientated for a road going bike but for a track bike they’re awesome little machines. Emphasis on the ‘little’ as they’re really tiny whereas the 675 is slim as it’s only a 3 cylinder engine.

It all comes down to personal preference when it comes down to buying one, I’ve got friends who will only buy Kawasaki/Suzuki because they really like the ergonomics of them.

Still, get a test ride when you can and make a decision, it’s what I done and I don’t regret it. :)[/quote]

Sadly since I’m only 17 I can’t get any of my R6’s on the road. I have to put up with a Yamaha R125 for the time being; I love the R6 on the track though, it’s an excellent bike.

I have a few friends who only buy Kawasaki’s for their gearbox. Especially their gearbox in the ER- range, I rode an ER-6n and I was amazed with it. Another great bike.

Read full topic

item.title: Motorcycles
item.dc:creator: @Ve_T Ve_T
item.description:
@Ve_T wrote:

I test rode an R6. Personally I thought it was a bit too top end orientated for a road going bike but for a track bike they’re awesome little machines. Emphasis on the ‘little’ as they’re really tiny whereas the 675 is slim as it’s only a 3 cylinder engine.

It all comes down to personal preference when it comes down to buying one, I’ve got friends who will only buy Kawasaki/Suzuki because they really like the ergonomics of them.

Still, get a test ride when you can and make a decision, it’s what I done and I don’t regret it.

Read full topic

item.title: Motorcycles
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

[quote=“Ve_T, post:39, topic:430531”]They never really use to appeal to me in all honesty. Before I passed my motorcycle test I wanted a 636 C1H but I test rode a Daytona and my mind was instantly changed.

If you can get your head past the whole R/R problems where they pretty much set fire to them selves (Yes, you have to keep on an eye on that, lol) then they’re a good bike. Brilliant mid range and a mad top end.[/quote]

Once I’m old enough to test drive a bike, I may just check one out. Unless I can get a loan of one at the track or stuff. One of the guys I used to race with had a Triumph and he said he preferred the R6. It’s just personal preference I suppose.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Ve_T Ve_T
item.description:
@Ve_T wrote:

They never really use to appeal to me in all honesty. Before I passed my motorcycle test I wanted a 636 C1H but I test rode a Daytona and my mind was instantly changed.

If you can get your head past the whole R/R problems where they pretty much set fire to them selves (Yes, you have to keep on an eye on that, lol) then they’re a good bike. Brilliant mid range and a mad top end.

@Ve_T wrote:

  1. What is your favorite motorcycle in terms of performance and design?

Triumph Daytona 675R

  1. If you could have any motorcycle in the world, which would you pick?

Triumph Daytona 675R

  1. What motorcycle do you currently have?

Triumph Daytona 675SE…

I’m such a fanboy it’s unreal. Spent a far amount getting mine sorted.

item.title: Motorcycles
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:31, topic:430531”][quote author=Ruby link=topic=533211.msg4078508#msg4078508 date=1345119690]

I have a Yz125, but I don’t use it much more, I’m not a big fan of motocross, not even for training purposes. It can be fun at times with other members of my team and stuff.

Admit it, you don’t like having to work your arse off riding it

I have to work my arse off riding the R6 just as much as I have to work on the crosser. Where the crosser is more physical riding, the R6 is more mental endurance and quick thinking.

I’m in no way trying to say that the R6 isn’t physically hard to ride, it is. And I’m not trying to say that the crosser isn’t mentally draining, because it is. I’m just stating that what one loses in one area, the other gains in the opposite. They’re two totally different riding styles and situations.
[/quote]
Well put. I’m aware of the differences, believe me.

Still, I’ve rode both, and there’s no greater physical/mental draining task then racing supercross on a 125 two-stroke - that shit’s tiring.[/quote]

I’ve never competitively raced a crosser before, the closest I’ve got was doing a charity super moto race which is fucking scary.

Those things are absolute monsters, I honestly thought I would break my neck.

Read full topic

item.title: Motorcycles
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“Ruby, post:30, topic:430531”][quote author=Yz85Racer link=topic=533211.msg4077694#msg4077694 date=1345011255]

I have a Yz125, but I don’t use it much more, I’m not a big fan of motocross, not even for training purposes. It can be fun at times with other members of my team and stuff.

Admit it, you don’t like having to work your arse off riding it
[/quote]
I have to work my arse off riding the R6 just as much as I have to work on the crosser. Where the crosser is more physical riding, the R6 is more mental endurance and quick thinking.

I’m in no way trying to say that the R6 isn’t physically hard to ride, it is. And I’m not trying to say that the crosser isn’t mentally draining, because it is. I’m just stating that what one loses in one area, the other gains in the opposite. They’re two totally different riding styles and situations.[/quote]
Well put. I’m aware of the differences, believe me.

Still, I’ve rode both, and there’s no greater physical/mental draining task then racing supercross on a 125 two-stroke - that shit’s tiring.

Read full topic

[/quote]
Admit it, you don’t like having to work your arse off riding it[/quote]
I have to work my arse off riding the R6 just as much as I have to work on the crosser. Where the crosser is more physical riding, the R6 is more mental endurance and quick thinking.

I’m in no way trying to say that the R6 isn’t physically hard to ride, it is. And I’m not trying to say that the crosser isn’t mentally draining, because it is. I’m just stating that what one loses in one area, the other gains in the opposite. They’re two totally different riding styles and situations.

item.title: Motorcycles
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

  1. What is your favorite motorcycle in terms of performance and design?
    R6. Best motorcycle in the world in my opinion, I’m a demonstration rider for Yamaha throughout Scotland. Used to race but I had a major crash last year and crushed half of my body.

  2. If you could have any motorcycle in the world, which would you pick?
    R6, I’ve rode R1’s and R125s, but I love the R6 more than any other bike, it’s just amazing.

  3. What motorcycle do you currently have?
    I currently have several, however a few I do not own.
    I have two 2012 R6’s, owned by Alan Duffus Yamaha, not myself, I use them for demonstration purposes.
    I have an R125 which I used to ride on the road since I’m British it was easy for me to pass my CBT, get insurance, tax it and be on the road.
    I have a Yz125, but I don’t use it much more, I’m not a big fan of motocross, not even for training purposes. It can be fun at times with other members of my team and stuff.
    I also have a Kawasaki ER-6N in orange, which I ride to work and back, to my girlfriends, just anywhere I don’t have to take the car.

Read full topic

item.title: Motorcycles
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:23, topic:430531”]not nesscarily

i can understand aussies not getting it though, you dont have greenery[/quote]
Yeah I’m not going to lie I had no fucking idea what green laning even was until I remembered I saw something about it on a show, and it was a range rover.

[quote=“Niall, post:24, topic:430531”][quote author=Yz85Racer link=topic=533211.msg3971705#msg3971705 date=1334214821]
Isn’t green laning done with a car?
[/quote]

many land/range rovers do green laning but it’s equally as accessible on bikes, I’d say more so due to the fact you can turn around at a dead end[/quote]
I don’t know too much about it, I assume it’s just bush-bashing as we like to call it, on a dirt bike? Look at a KLZ/DRZ/WRF or some other type of off-road bike. I can’t imagine you’d want the balls-to-the-wall feel of a motocross bike, but you probably don’t want the gutless-granny feeling of say a DRZ400. I’d suggest the WRF-450f?

Read full topic
